Prompt:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 200 words. 
Prehistory was a time long ago, when humans first appeared on earth. During this time, humans did not write down their history. Instead, they passed it down through stories and paintings on the walls of caves. This is why we have to be very careful when studying prehistory - we have to use our imagination and think like the people who lived during that time. Imagine that you are a young hunter, living in a small village. You have to be brave and resourceful, because you have to protect your family from the dangers of the wild. You have to know how to make tools and build shelters, and how to find food in the forest. This is what life was like for people during prehistory. We can learn about this time by studying the things they left behind, like the tools they used and the paintings they made on the walls of caves. By studying prehistory, we can get a glimpse of what life was like for our ancestors.

Prehistory is the time before written records began. It's a time when humans were hunter-gatherers. People would follow large animals like mammoths and gather fruits, nuts, and berries. They also fished and hunted for small animals like rabbits. The people of prehistory were highly skilled. They could make tools from stones and wood. They built shelters to protect themselves from the weather and made clothes to keep warm. People also learned how to farm. They discovered how to plant seeds, which led to the growth of cities and eventually, civilizations. As they learned and grew, they were able to create better tools and homes. They were able to live in one place for a long time, which allowed them to create more complex societies. The people of prehistory were able to survive and thrive in many different environments. They were resourceful and clever

During prehistory, humans did not yet have written records. There were no books, no newspapers, and no written messages. People told stories through art, like paintings on cave walls. These images helped to pass down history and traditions from one generation to another. Archaeologists study the artifacts left behind by our ancestors, like tools, bones, and pottery. These relics reveal the lives of early humans, how they lived, what they ate, and how they hunted. The artifacts also show how humans developed and changed over time. By piecing together the evidence, archaeologists can reconstruct the past and learn about the people who lived before us. For example, they have discovered ancient tools made of stone, like hammers and knives, and even early forms of writing, like hieroglyphics. These findings have helped us understand the earliest chapters of human history. By studying the past, we can learn more about ourselves and our place in the world. Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 200 words. 

Prehistory was a long, long time ago. People during this time didn't leave behind many written records. That's why it's called "prehistory." However, archaeologists have discovered many other clues that help us learn about the people who lived then. They've found tools, weapons, and other objects that were made by hand. By studying these objects, we can figure out what life was like for our ancestors. For example, we can tell what they ate by looking at the bones they left behind. We can also see how they built their homes and what kinds of clothes they wore. By piecing together all these clues, we can get a picture of what life was like in prehistory. People were likely very skilled at making things and living off the land. They were also very resourceful, using materials they found in nature to create the tools they needed. By studying prehistory, we can learn about the people who came before us and how they lived.

Prehistory is the period of human history before written records were kept. Before prehistory, there was no written history. The first human civilizations appeared in the Middle East around 4000 BCE. One of the most famous civilizations of prehistory is the Sumerians, who built the first cities and developed writing. 

Prehistory is a time long, long ago when humans didn't keep records. They didn't write down what they did, so we can't know much about what happened. But we can guess some things. People started living in groups and building houses, around 4000 years ago. This is when the first cities were built. We call these people the Sumerians. They are famous for building cities and developing writing. Without writing, we wouldn't have much to learn from, so the Sumerians were very important. They started keeping records of their time, and these records helped us learn about the past. Now we can imagine what life was like back then

Prehistory is a time before history was recorded. Many discoveries have been made to uncover the lives of people who lived before written records existed. Fossils of early humans and animals were found in rocks and caves. These discoveries helped us learn how ancient people lived, what they ate, and how they dressed. We found tools that early humans used to survive. We also discovered ancient paintings on cave walls and rocks, which showed how people expressed themselves. The study of prehistory has given us a glimpse into the lives of people who came before us, revealing their cultures, traditions, and ways of life. It is a time that is still being studied and learned about today, and it continues to help us understand our place in the world and how we evolved to be who we are today. By studying prehistory, we can learn about the past and appreciate the present.

Prompt:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 200 words. 

Prehistory was a long time ago. People lived, but there were no written records of their lives. They did not write down their thoughts or stories. However, archaeologists have found many clues to tell us what people were like during that time. They dug up old bones and discovered tools made from stone and wood. Some tools were for hunting, while others were for making clothes. Archaeologists also found remains of old homes and tools used for farming. They even found the remains of old animals, like mammoths, that people hunted for food. By looking at these clues, we can piece together what life was like for people during prehistory. We know that people had to work hard to survive, and they had to adapt to their surroundings to find food and shelter. By studying these clues, we can learn about the lives of people who lived a long time ago and imagine what they might have been like. They are like puzzles that help us understand our history.  ​
